It's NOT like a pinwheel though, that's incorrect, if it were like a pinwheel the rotation of the blades would have to be the opposite, but that doesn't happen, it still keeps moving the same way. This bugged me for a long time until I researched how Gyrocopters work, to put it simply, if you adjust the pitch of the blades the right way, the way the wind hits it from the bottom but at an angle, this makes the airfoil of the blade produce lift that is pointed not straight up but forward, the same direction the helicopter is flying in, causing the blades to spin forward (same way) as well. Pilot increases the rotation spin of the blades using this technique and right at the end pitches (or flares) the blades to produce lift back, causing the blades to slow down (but produce a lot of lift) and the helicopter slows down as well.

P.S If the pilot flared the blades right when the engine died at the high altitude, that would make the blades come to a complete stop and maybe turn backwards (don't know if that's even possible), now THAT would be like a pinwheel, it would also make the helicopter drop like a rock.

You could have done this with an R/C helicopter. R/C helicopters, especially large scale R/C helicopters tend to have good disk loading. I small 250 R/C helicopter is pretty bad at autorotations, but say a 700 class will float very nicely. I suppose this is another thing is you don't want to try an autorotation in a Superstallion. The Superstallion pilots I have talked to said all of their buddies who tried this crashed. At least for my larger R/C helicopters when I was flying, I would always autorotate in. It is actually safer because in addition to those ships being fairly floaty, making it easy to autorotate them, the big concern is hitting the ground wrong under power or having the vibrations of the helicopter on the ground with the vibrations of being at full power reverberating off of the ground and causing a gyro to misread due to the vibrations and flip the helicopter on the ground while under power. (Usually with R/C helicopters you use an electric 3-axis based gyro to stabilize the helicopter, though it is an option to use a mechanical flybar.) If you autorotate in and bleed off the rotor speed, you can reverse collective again close to the ground and make a nice, gentle, low blade kinetic energy landing. Also for high speed fast forward flight autorotations, at least if you have strong metal blade grips (I have seen many plastic ones fail on other R/C helicopter pilots, so will never buy a kit with plastic ones), you can really spin up those blades and I have been able to stop the forward momentum when doing the final blade reverse and plopping the helicopter onto the ground without skidding and without any damage. It is a bit tricky and normally I just go vertical when doing the final approach.

One major correction I would put in there is I have crashed while the blades were spinning while attempting an emergency autorotation while partially inverted. After the umbrella gears to the tail rotor stripped, I ended up in a blade stall while trying to bring it in after hitting throttle hold. (When you have at least nubs rubbing against each other, the tail blades still spin some and sometimes you can stop the out of control pirouetting by cutting the power, thus eliminating the torque causing the out of control pirouetting and the small amount of force from the slowly spinning tail rotor is enough to halt the pirouetting if you have enough space before hitting the ground. Out of control pirouetting is an extra challenge when trying to flip your helicopter back over to a skids down position instead of a skids up position as in it is a special skill to know how to do a piro-flip when under control, let alone when that control is gone.) A blade stall can be the rotors are spinning, but the airflow is turbulent as in a stall. So helicopters stall just like planes except instead of not having enough forward speed to maintain laminar air flow over the wings, causing the angle of attack to be too great, the rotor is not spinning fast enough to maintain laminar air flow over the rotor blades. So it looks like you might be able to save the helicopter from major damage, but then when you do the final reversal on collective, it just keeps going down like you didn't do anything and then you hear loud noises from the impact. The ground judges swiftly and the ground judges harshly.

He was probably referring to the "seized engine" type of failure. "Seized engine" means the engine is unable to turn. On a propeller plane you can "feather" the propeller on the seized engine, reducing its drag drastically. On the other side if the rotor of the helicopter is unable to rotate at all, you are indeed a brick. Thus an engine on a helicopter must be constructed in a way that the "seizure" is insanely unlikely to happen. Basically, you can't just bolt the rotor onto the engine, there must be some sort of slip bearing between the two, permitting the rotor to rotate even when the engine gets stuck.

I can totally imagine that early helicopter designs were prone to this "falls down like rock" and after investigation the construction was modified to permit this autorotation failsafe feature.

NOT true,  helicopters do not glide like an airplane,  autorotate will allow about 4/5 of a mile for every 1000' of altitude.  Nothing  like a Cessna 172, or a Cirrus SR-22, cam glide about 1 1/2 miles for every 1,000' of altitude.   That reduces the options where to land by more than half.

In my military career I was both an Army and an Air Force instructor pilot in the UH-1 Huey helicopter. Army pilots are trained to make autorotation landings that slide after touchdown (like Gerry did).  The Air Force required touchdowns to have no slide because you are more likely to land on a soft surface - dirt, mud, water, treetops, etc - than you are a runway.  This was done by just before landing pulling the nose up to reduce forward speed and to build rotor RPM, then transitioning to a hovering autorotation (just as if your engine failed in a hover). I always thought the Air Force way was a better idea.

One of the times, I remember his radio captured his voice during descent and he exclaimed something foreboding (forgot the words) as he was about to come down into one of the many ponding basins throughout the city. These particular Robbies have a reputation of crashing and having been at the controls of one it's not hard to understand why. I have to be honest here. I hardly understood a sentence uttered in this video. I had the privilege of fly a helicopter once. Its was one of these adventures in which the pilot gives you a run down of about 20 minutes of what we were going to do then I would be given the controls at two thousand feet and basically fly the vehicle. What surprised me was how very little input was needed for the helicopter controls to carry out whatever it is the pilot was doing. Whenever you see in movies etc someone flying a helicopter they make it so dramatic. You see the pilot pushing the stick super hard at jarring levels and in reality its nowhere near that. The amount of touch needed on the stick to direct the vehicle is very little. Also what was amazing was experiencing a a free fall drop from 2000 ft to 400 ft in seconds, lol. I yelled out like a little girl even though I knew it was coming. I was then given the opportunity to try to maintain a hover of about six to ten feet off the ground while the pilot explained what to do. I found this to be the most difficult maneuver. I actually was not successful after a number of tries. Your trying to keep the tail from whipping around and maintaining this balance. Like I said it was only once I got to experience it but it was one of the most exciting things I've ever done. I would love to do it more and actually get my license to pilot a copter. There is so much to learn before being able to actually get to the point of soloing. Its a dream I pray I can one day achieve. God bless every pilot out there truly a special breed...

No thanks. Auto rotation is a controlled crash. Auto rotation to the ground is rarely done in training EXACTLY BECAUSE it is an extremely dangerous maneuver in a very lightweight structure that can crumple from net to nothing.

An airplane merely becomes a low performance glider. In my Cessna 172's, I can glide 8,000 feet (over a mile) for every 1,000 feet of altitude. There will be somewhere to land safely unless I'm in some pretty rough wilderness.....and at which time I wouldn't be flying a C 172, I'd be in something like a Piper Cub or some other STOL bird that can land in less distance than that helicopter in the video just slid.

Oh, I'm a fixed wing pilot (a bit of bias), and a former aircraft mechanic and QA inspector for fixed and rotary wing aircraft.. That and rotary wing mech and inspector experience tells me....stay the heck out of flop wings....they'll kill you.

Also, a lot of fighter type aircraft, for example the F15 and T38, turn into a "pumpkin" if they lose both engines. Lose both engines and you lose ALL electrical and perhaps more importantly, ALL hydraulics. AKA NO flight controls. AKA you Eject. Fighters do not glide.

I was a U.S. Army helicopter pilot and part of my time spent in the Army was as an instructor pilot. I taught the 1st 50 hours of flight instruction., out of a 210 hr. course. Before our students moved onto the 2nd phase of instruction they had to learn and complete 3 solo autorotations (to touchdown). Scores of practice autorotations were done prior to that.
When an autorotation is entered the pilot bottoms out the collective, applies pedal to keep to aircraft from yawing and turns into the wind, looking for a suitable landing area. The aircraft is put into an angle of descent that keeps the rotor RPM at an optimal speed. At NO time is the collective used to control the rotor speed during descent. Just before touchdown the aircraft is flared (to slow it down), leveled out, and then collective is applied to soften the landing.

"He's gonna flare it" is not enough level of detail for anyone to actually understand this, we can only pretend that we do, yuck it up good feelings, a game I don't like to play.
When powered, the rotor leading edge angle is up to push air down but with loss of power, that angle would sweep the rotor in the reverse direction. I don't think that's what happens. So maybe more information is needed on how much rotor pitch adjustment is available from the lever by the seat (the so-called "collective"). From the end of the rotor, I want to look down the length of it watching that rotation's full extent of movement, pointing out its rest position, and then versus it's likely range in autorotation emergency landing mode. This is why I did well in school, I never accepted "He's gonna flare it"-type explanations because they only go for sounding good instead of really conveying understanding.

Further, on the topic of helicopters... To help quench misinformation: if you lose the tail-rotor, you are still able to fly the chopper safely.... You simply have to fly it like a plane by increasing your forward momentum.. You lose your vertical take off and landing capability without the rear stabilizer because if you fly too slowly forwards, as you aren't being stabilized with counter-rotation, and rotate / spin - which you can recover from, but if you fly it forward, quickly, it self-stabilizes.... This is also a reason why there are skid-pads on helicopters instead of landing 'legs', on most anyway... Or if there are landing legs they should have a ski style to them to allow sliding.

I was in the United States Coast Guard in the early 70s and I watched a lieutenant autogyro a Sikorsky HH3F. He was doing fine until about the last hundred feet and I guess he sneezed or something because from there it did fall like a brick. It fell so hard it broke all five rotors. To make matters worse, it was a drill and we were on scene and I was in command of the boat. I Radioed the helicopter pilot and told him whatever he did, “do not deploy flotation”. The reason is, on a Sikorsky HH3F, the port flotation deploys first, which rolls the open door underwater and the thing then sinks like a brick. The lieutenant asked me what my rate was and I told him and he told me he was not going to take orders from an enlisted man and did it anyway. He was forced to resign his commission after that. Oh, and the helicopter? Yes, it definitely sank like a brick. No lives were lost; just one officer’s commission. 🤣

Read a book: Chickenhawk, by Robert Mason, who was a 1st Cav pilot in Vietnam.  He explained how to deal with autorotation this way:  If you are flying at 500+ feet, you drop the collective and the cyclic to keep the blades spinning or else the main rotor will fold up and...God help you.  As you descend, pick a spot to land.  This happens in 5-8 seconds.  If you are hovering under 100 feet, pull up the collective and keep the cyclic level best you can.  Mason said it happens so fast, you don' have time to think.  Thus the training.  One wrong move, and...well, God help you.  After reading that book, glad I was mechanized infantry!

It's called "AUTOROTATION". So, if the helicopter engine fails, the pilot reaches out and pulls a lever which engages a clutch that seperates the "Blades and Drive Shaft" from the "Engine" enabling the blades to continue to "Spin Freely". During helicopter flight "Tremendous Weight" is produced at the tip of "Each Blade" (40 to 60Ton) depending on helicopter type, so when the pilot engages the "Clutch" its this weight that enables the blades to keep spinning hence, hopefully allowing the pilot to land safely! During helicopter pilot training, pilots have to practice this manouver using what's called a "Power Down or On, Autorotation! I was a helicopter tech for years and have been a passenger in Gazelle Heli's while trainee pilots practiced this manouver from about 5000 feet down to roughly 1000 feet. Great Buzz, loved it!

It's been my understanding that the blades of a helicopter are not a propeller but rather a wing. The same principle applies to the helicopter blades as an airplane wing. The blades rotate maintaining airflow over the top of the blades which generates lift. The same way a gliding airplane moves forward through the air to keep the air flowing over the wing to generate lift.

I was pretty confused by the comment he makes right after 3:47, about being able to control how much of the blade is used as a pinwheel vs a fan. At first I thought it must be wrong, but now I think it makes sense if you think about it as a fan blowing *upwards*, which was not at all clear from the video. (It's also possible that I'm still mistaken/confused.)

To see why (I think) it couldn't be a fan blowing downwards:

1) Stick your right arm out to the side with your palm facing down, and imagine that it is a helicopter blade. Now tilt your arm slightly so that your thumb is pointing slightly up, and imagine what would happen if you swung your right arm forward (or if you were spinning counter-clockwise when viewed from above). You would create lift. Your arm would act as a fan pushing air downward.

2) Now consider if air started rushing up from underneath you (because you were falling perhaps, but somehow still maintaining a stable orientation). If you didn't change the tilt at all on your arm, then this would cause your arm to swing backwards (or cause you to spin clockwise when viewed from above) -- the opposite direction of spin from before. If instead you did change the tilt of your arm such that now your thumb was pointing slightly downwards, then you could continue spinning counter-clockwise, as before. Your arm is now acting as a pinwheel, where the air rushing from underneath is causing it to spin, slowing your descent. However, since the part of your arm-blade furthest away from you is moving through the air faster than the part in the middle, it might be moving through the air so fast that it's effectively pushing air upwards. It's also experiencing drag, and slowing your rotation.

So it seems to me that air moving over the pinwheel part of the blades causes the blades to rotate and slows your decent, while the outermost part of the blade is moving so fast that 1) it's experiencing significant drag, slowing the rotation of the blades, and 2) it's actually pushing air upwards, such that if it weren't for the pinwheel part, it would actually speed up your descent.

So then the trick is getting the blade tilt angle right so that you balance the rotational thrust and drag, and also the positive and negative vertical lift from the pinwheel and fan portions respectively. That's my layman's guess anyway.

@3:07, The engine does not act like a big fan blowing down air. A Helicopter is a "rotor wing" aircraft. This means the rotors are shaped like a wing and produce lift with pressure differentials, like a wing on a traditional fixed wing aircraft. When the rotors are spinning, they produce lift, you can adjust the collective pitch to gain lift, or negative pitch to loose it. A Helicopter does not have enough thrust to lift itself by pushing the air "like a fan". Another fun fact, Helicopter does not break down to Heli or Copter like some people shorten them to, it's Actually from the Greek Helico (spiral) and Pter (wing).

A small information on helicopter controls :
Collective changes the pitch angle on the rotor “collectively”. If you increase or decrease the collective all the pitch angles on the rotor system increase or decrease at the same time.
Cyclic changes the pitch angles on the rotor “cyclically”. If you give an input the pitch angles change according to your input 90 degrees before because of the gyroscopic laws. The system used for these inputs is named Swashplate.

10,000 hours to be a master, but all it takes is only one time to lose it all!  Safe than a plane?   That depends on the type of helicopter your trying to autorotate, and those private little toy copters aren't speaking for all helicopter-kind; If autorotation were that easy, most people would survive these situations, but do not.   Because when things do go wrong, in a helicopter, it's usually life changing, due to circumstances, such as conflict of war, bad weather, etc.  How often do critical things go wrong on a bright sunny day... I'd take my chances gliding in with a plane, than in a vehicle with a lawn mower attached above your head.

I think the reason the perception is that a helicopter drops like a brick, is because you MUST keep the rotors spinning, and I believe that the propellers can be unlocked to allow them to spin (I was wrong about the unlocking), they can change the pitch of the propellers, otherwise, the helicopter would only be stabilized against spinning in circles, but not from falling like a brick...  So if the propellers are unresponsive, you will essentially drop like a giant brick and the landing will be quite memorable, if you survive.

I remember back in the 80's or 90's, there was a video game called LHX Attack Chopper which allowed you to autorotate, but it was hit or miss, because there is little to no room for mistakes in the process.  It's a translation of weight, and trying to make the helicopter as weightless as possible, which can't happen without the propellers, even should the rotors be functional, just isn't enough.  My advice to anyone caught in that situation... Grow feathers quickly and learn how to use them!

a portion of the blades, with collective lowered, has negative pitch...its this that gives the 'drive' to maintain the rotors rpm. Yes, its by raising the collective you can prevent an overspeed during an 'auto' (I used to work on Helis, 'auto' checks were mandatory after changing a rotor head.  Too slow an rpm meant not enough negative pitch, too fast meant too much negative pitch)

When I was a young Medic recruit at Ft Sam, we got to be strapped into a exterior rescue stretcher that would be attached above the skids of old UH-1 Iroquoy Hueys, and get taken for a ride in a simulated Medivac over the post.
What we didn't know was that there was a fine tradition amongst the aviators: to mess with us young trainees.
They would fly NOE at high speed, then climb very high at a steep angle, then cut the drive to the rotors, and basically drop the collective into a straight down free fall, and the crew cheif would start screaming "WE'RE GOING DOWN! WE'RE GOING DOWN!"
Needless to say, being strapped into a stretcher above the skids, hearing the screaming and seeing us all drop LIKE A BRICK, I came close to needed some new BDU trousers.
They laughed maniacally when they re-engaged full flight momentum with less than 100 feet back down to the ground. I didn't think it was very funny.

This is a bit misleading. Helicopters glide, but hardly. They pretty much fall. The altitude to glide ratio is poor and that only exists if you have forward momentum. As far as autorotation goes, you're just slowing the fall - but that ability is limited. Look up helicopters autorotating and see how well that typically works in the real world. With engine failure, planes land at the same speed they normally land. They only land hard or tumble if there's nowhere safe to land (no obstructions). With that, helicopters have the same problem: trees, buildings, signage, poles, wires, etc. At least with a plane, once your engine goes out, you have plenty of time to pick out a safe landing spot - even a nearby airport. With a failed heli engine, you drop right away and have little to no choice of where you want to land. A Cessna will glide about 1.5 miles for every 1000 feet of altitude you have. In my experience waiting for a Cessna 172, with a failed engine, to reach the ground can be quite long and actually boring - in training at least! LOL!

Fun fact:  Robinson's are basically bricks when the engine fails.  They don't meet the minimum auto-rotation standards for the UK which is they are no longer allowed to be commercially flown over urban areas in the UK. Actually NZ was recently thinking about banning them from being imported or operated in the country at all.

First---beautiful footage! I've got to get up to British Columbia some time....really want to get to Canada in general. Never been there, but everything I've seen shows it to be a really gorgeous place. I'm just a winter wimp...

Second---I took training in helicopters myself years ago...wanted to get dual-rated for both fixed-wing and rotary-wing. Didn't come to pass unfortunately---ran short on money, cut back to the fixed wing. I miss it. Took my training in Schweizer 300CBs, which is the civilian version of the U.S. Army's TH-55. (Can't believe you were brave enough to go up in a Robinson---those helos kinda have a reputation....)

The points presented are a bit exaggerated. It is true that helicopters don't just fall STRAIGHT down, but their glide ratio is not great. They do tend to drop pretty fast---ask a helo pilot about settling with power and vortex ring state sometime. Gets scary. Anyway...autorotations, at least in the Schweizer, were actually a pretty gentle ride until you got to the ground. Then things get busy---keep the nose straight, don't let it start turning, get coordinated on cyclic/collective, don't flare too high or you'll lose all that reserve power in the rotor, flare just like the pilot in your video, then....just let it settle. If you've done everything right, it's really not bad. If you haven't...well...

The main rotor on an American, English, German and Italian helicopter spins counter-clockwise. The main rotor on French and Russian helicopters spins clockwise as observed from the pilots POV. The result is that the pedals that control the tail-rotor of the respective AC work in the opposite direction. Add left pedal when adding power to the counter-clockwise main rotor AC and add right pedal when adding power to the clockwise rotating main rotor AC. ( From a former US Army CW2 helicopter pilot. )

Made some comments when this great video was first posted, and now that I visit again a year later I see a lot of misunderstanding from commenters with not much help setting them straight. I am a low-time pilot without about 160 hours in helicopters and 70 hours in airplanes. Let me see if I can answer some questions I saw in the comments:

1) all helicopters can autorotate. No one would build one that could not (not sure if you even could) and if they did it would not get certified. That said, some birds auto a lot "nicer" than others. I have only flown two kinds of helos: Enstrom piston and Hughes/Schweizer/Sikorsky 300 which is also piston. I have done way over 100 autos (all with recovery on the bottom, i.e. not "full-down" like in this video). An auto in an Enstrom is kind of like a non-event. The rotor is heavy enough that it has a bunch of energy from its weight which makes it almost like you are landing under power. The 300 has light blades so the autorotation has a lot more drama (plus the nose points toward the ground a lot more which "feels" scary). lighter the rotor the less time you have to get the collective down and start letting the wind spin the rotor for you, and once you are in the auto you still are flying in that you need to keep the rotor RPM in the safe zone by lifting the collective (it will overspeed if you do not) and you have all your flying functions (if you had a tailwind when you lost power, you turn 180 degrees while in the auto as you always want to auto into the wind if you can).

In any event, you can get it done and even if you did not land perfectly, when you hit the ground you are going very close to 0 knots compared to a Cessna 172 for example having a full flap stall speed of 47 knots so you are going to hit the ground going at least 40 knots. Fine if you are on a road, but a serious problem in rough terrain.

2) all helicopter pilots can do autos. It is part of the practical test you take to get your license and part of the biannual review you have to get every two years. This includes autorotations from a hover. Yes you can auto from any speed and any height above ground - although it is going to be a tough ask at low speed and low altitude. I used to fly out of a hangar next to the MD factory in Mesa, AZ and watch them do their advanced training. They would do auto after auto from less than 500 feet AGL and zero airspeed. It was scary as heck to watch (nose was pointed straight down until they flared really hard) but they got it done every time. Airspeed REALLY helps (this is why police and news helicopters like to fly circles when they are monitoring something on the ground), but it is not necessary. This is why we take off and land helicopters kind of like airplanes. Taking off at an angle and landing at an angle gives you at least some speed to maybe get the auto done if you lose power (should not be a problem on the way out without obstructions, but it going to bring on serious pucker on the way in).

3) the main rotor and tail rotor are mechanically connected on all helicopters, so when you are using the wind of falling to spin the rotor it is also powering the tail rotor, BUT note that the job of the tail rotor is to counteract the torque of the engine, so if you lose the engine you no longer need the torque compensation of the tail rotor. Some commenter properly noted that because of this, an autorotation is the solution to an in-flight tail rotor failure. If you somehow lost your tail rotor in flight, the wind created by the speed of your helo will keep the tail behind you, but you are not going to have control when you slow down. So solution is fly at speed to a safe place then enter an autorotation and land without power.

Sorry so long. Hope that helps those of you who are interested in helicopters.
OMG, Neil DeGrasse Tyson was wrong about something? I am genuinely astonished.

Situation: turbine driven helicopter (i.e. a Huey), low forward airspeed, low altitude, an emergency maneuver to quickly gain altitude (avoid wires) by pulling collective (and throttling up). Result: pulling collective increases the pitch of the rotor and produces more lift (to "pop up" over the wires) but dramatically slows the main rotor and the load on the rotor slows the turbine engine. Turbines take time (seconds, not instantaneous) to regain speed (i.e. "spool up"). In the mean time, the helicopter drops, not like a brick, more like a leaf, but definitely not like an autorotation. The downward fall does force air through the rotor (the pinwheel effect) which helps to speed up the rotor and helps to maintain some control (while still descending). In this instance (first hand experience), rotor speed and engine speed recovered sufficiently to avoid hitting the ground. Not certain a favorable outcome could be predicted in all cases. Your expert may have an opinion. No, I was not the pilot but I was present.
Basically a plane without engines turns into a glider (an inperfect one, with a relatively high drag), while a helicopter - into an autogyro (into a way too complex one).
But the back rotator, though. If it fails, the chopper starts to spin wildly out of control.

Autorotation is not always possible. There is an airspeed vs altitude chart that you need to be within. This is why when you see helicopters take off from an air field they will use the run way to generate forward airspeed before altitude. It's more critical for single engine helicopters. Helicopters used for search and rescue that hover at low altitude with no forward airspeed are well outside the safe autorotation parameters and need to have a second engine for safety.

The physics is confusing, but apparently helicopter blades are twisted so they have a sharper angle near the rotor and are more flat as they go to the edge. At the center of the circle is the stall region where the angle is too sharp and will produce drag. near the middle of the blade the driving region, the airspeed is not too fast and the angle is more shallow so that there is lift to slow down the helicopter's descent. The outer tips of the blade, the driven region,  also does not help much too because the horizontal airspeed is too fast to produce much lift. The stall and driven region produce more drag on the blades while the driving region produces more lift. By lowering the angle of the blades at the moment of engine failure, the pilot can minimize the drag on the blades and also enlarge the driving region.

I'm going to have to say that calling helicopter blades "giant fans" is an absolutely gross over-simplification of what they actually are. They are literally rotating wings. They use lift in the exact same way as airplane wings do. The way they differ is how they manipulate the air flowing over them. An airplane simply moves part of its wing as the airflow is greatest over the outer part of the wing, but since a helicopter wing is rotating, the whole thing has to be tilted in order to properly manipulate airflow and get a response. This of course is done through what is called a swash plate via small arms that rotate on it and are connected to the pivot joints on the blades. This swash plate can tilt and raise or lower and as it does, the rods move up and down as they go around the plate and force the blades to tilt up and down as well. This forces lift at certain areas of the rotation causing the helicopter to move in whatever direction the pilot wants as he moves the collective or the control column. That's how they work basically. They are not fan blades and should not be thought of as such. if you look at their shape you will see that it is not conducive to the flow of air downwards. They are designed in a way where, much like an airplane wing, it causes pressure differences between the upper and lower parts of the  blade. Downward air movement is a consequence of this action but it is by no means the driving force behind how helicopters take off. That's just my two cents and basic knowledge on how helicopters work but it bothers me when i hear people treating helicopters like they are giant fans. Yes they move a lot of air but only by consequence of the action they are actually using to achieve lift.

Anyone who implies that all helicopters that (manage to) autorotate, land at a stately 10 MPH has limited emergency or crash investigation experience. You need to access the FAA records of all the civilian and military helicopter crashes in the New York / New Jersey area over the last 30 years, particularly "TV News / Traffic" helicopters, sightseeing helicopters or commuter helicopters that have lost power and had to make emergency "landings" on land or in water (like the Hudson River). Pull the video clips or tapes of the survivors (in incidents where there were survivors!) describing their experiences. Neither a pleasant or gentle experience as your film implies. This story of gentle, controlled landings while auto rotating was the same sad story owners and pilots of gyrocopters in the 1970's and 1980's were told, until videos of actual crashes showed them coming in speeds at 50 to 60 MPH (forward motion while auto-rotating), and then tumbling nose over tail until finally coming to a rest as a small pile of junk. I applaud your enthusiasm and desire to make interesting learning videos, but next time, you need to check your facts with more than just "one expert".

On average a helicopter will have a 18°-20° glide angle where a small Cessna will have a 6°-7° glide angle. A boeing 787 or Airbus 330 will have a glide angle of 3°-4°! So even though a helicopter doesn't fall you have to look down for a landing spot. A small cessna like plane at 3000 ft will glide over 4.5 miles where a helicopter just barely passes a mile. Another point to consider is typical use. Helicopters are usually used for short trips or sightseeing. In both these cases they are going to be at a low altitude. This means that any failures are going to limit auto-rotation distance greatly. In comparison airplanes are usually at a much higher altitude increasing the already better glide ratio.

Welllll, helos certainly are RELATIVELY bricklike. As an average, an unpowered helicopter will have a glide ratio of about 3:1 (three feet forward, 1 foot down) at a certain speed. Something like a Cessna 172 would have a glide ratio of perhaps 10:1. So a loss of power occurrence in a helicopter gives you a much smaller area from which to choose a suitable landing area. The huge advantage the helo has is that if energy is skillfully managed, it is possible to land with virtually zero airspeed. In a light aircraft you are going to hit whatever surface you've chosen (be it a highway, a lake, trees, residential areas etc..) at around 50mph, give or take. By the way, many jetliners have glide ratios of over 20:1, some are well over that, which makes them equal to some very good sailplanes.

you get one chance at a successful autorotation,
and you have little choice in where you actually land.
if there is not a helicopter sized open area for a few hundred yards in any direction at the time of engine failure you are screwed.

while it varies alot by the aircraft, a typical general aviation light aircraft like the cessna 172 has a 9 to 1 glide ratio for every foot of altitude lost, it will gain 9 feet of distance. airliners glide better still, with ratios in the 17 to 1 possible. the only issue here is if the aircrafts flight controls are a fly by wire type, without mechanical backup, if you loose your engines, and your emergency ramair turbine spools down due to low airspeed you'll loose the ability to operate your control surfaces.

a helicopter with no power falls out of the sky like a brick, you disengage the rotors and allow them to pinwheel in the slipstream,
at the last minute before impact you yank the collective pitch control and take a big bite of air with those pin wheeling blades and you have a few moments to find a safe place to land, and set it down.

I think you failed in explaining the major part of autorotation. The key is: helicopter rotorblade is not - as most people would think - a giant fan blade that blows air downward to keep helicopter in air. It is in fact a wing that uses the same aerodynamic forces like the fix wing does to generate lift. Therefore as long as you keep the rotorblades spinning fast enough, it will generate enough lift to keep helicopter from falling like a brick, regardless of whether the wind is blowing upwards or downwards. It all comes down to the AOA factor.

A slight technical error in your description of how the rotor produces lift. It is NOT a giant fan, blowing air downward, although it looks like that, especially during takeoff.

The rotor blades are actually wings - shaped just like an aircraft wing, and the motion of the curved surface through the air creates lift due to the induced pressure differential between the upper and lower surfaces of the rotor blade.

This is why helicopter flight is called "rotary wing" as against "fixed wing" of a normal aircraft.
(note ; things like quadcopters ARE fans - each rotor is a propellor, not a wing) :)

Hey Destin ! Great video , I have an interesting question about this video, At 4 minutes and 5 seconds into the video you show the circular rotor disc of the helicopter. The red part of the circle is where the rotor disc acts as a pinwheel while the green part is where the rotor acts like a fan. I couldn't help but notice that the green circle is shifted just a bit to the left, and if this image is accurate then there is more area working as a fan on the left side as compared to the right side this should cause the helicopter to pitch forward due to gyroscopic precession, this is not in line with the previous image where the helicopter pitches back during autorotation, and if the helicopter has to pitch back then the green circle shown in the video should be shifted towards right half of the rotor disc this will cause more lift on the right side and consequently gyroscopic precession will cause the helicopter to pitch back. This makes more sense because of the concept of dissymmetry of lift, the advancing blade will generate more lift than the retreating blade, this is where I have a doubt.
Also for autorotation to occur the pitch of the blades has to be negative, only then will they continue spinning CCW and if the blades have negative pitch then how will they act as a fan blowing air downwards? It will only blow air upwards.
I am confused can you please clarify !

I was a crewman on HH-3Fs and HH-60Js in the USCG and we'd practice autos all the time.

I remember the first time I experienced one. The pilots pulled the engine control levers back to ground idle and there was this crazy silence after the engines spooled down; All I could hear was the main rotor (whisper mode!). In straight and level flight, if there is an engine failure then autorotate lowering the collective and maintain main rotor rpm and minimum airspeed while you are in the glide to a safe spot to land, then flair (raise the collective increasing rotor pitch) right before the skids touch the ground to cushion your landing.  If you lose tail rotor effectiveness, then it turns into a run on landing, basically you are at a low approach to the runway (hopefully a runway or a hard and even surface) and maintain the helicopter's heading by using the throttle causing engine torque making the nose point right or left, then you basically skid down the hard surface, raise the collective to stop skidding.  If the engine fails in a hover, you maintain heading (the direction the helicopter is facing) and  just flair (raise the collective increasing rotor pitch) right before the skids hit the ground.

+SmarterEveryDay Ahhhh! Helicopters are not "safer", for several reasons:

1. Helicopters tend to fly lower, meaning that the time between an engine failure and touchdown is much shorter than with a fixed-wing aircraft.
2. Helicopters don't have a glide ratio that is comparable to most planes (basically only fighter planes with tiny wings glide worse). What that means is that if you have an engine failure, not only did you start lower, but you have much less range to find a suitable landing area for a given amount of altitude. Granted, a "suitable landing area" for a helicopter under autorotation is much smaller than that one for a fixed-wing aircraft!
3. The descent rates for helicopters under autorotation tend to be higher than for planes. Many military helicopters autorotate with a descent rate that can cause injury to their crews.

There is a book called Chickenhawk by Robert Mason (really good read if you like helicopters) it's an auto-biography about Mason's experiences as a UH-1 pilot during the vietnam war.
He states:

The army taught us to fly the machine as if the engine would quit at any moment.
Throughout training, whether you were trying to hover, take off, land, or just cruise,
the IP (instructor pilot) would cut the power, to see how you'd react. When he decided you might
survive a real emergency alone, then you would solo.
My IP, Tom Anderson, would wait to cut the power until we were crabbing
sideways or bucking in somebody's rotor wash or ballooning too high in a hover. He
wanted to see how we would react when everything else was going wrong. There
was no way you could be ready for it. We learned to react automatically when the
power quit.

Scary but necessary.

The key to autorotation is to keep the blade rotation speed at 100% (there is a gauge for that). As long as the blades are spinning at their optimum speed, you're safe. Going down, the blade speed is the most important thing. Then there comes a time when you trade off downward velocity for blade rotation. Do it right, and the landing is soft, and the blades are spinning slowly.
The more inertia in the blades the better. That is why the Huey had just two blades, it was almost guaranteed you were able to autorotate safely. The newer helicopters with lots of smaller blades have less blade inertia, and are more difficult to autorotate. The more blades, the quieter, more agile, and efficient they are. But then again, newer helicopters have more mature and reliable engines than the Huey had.

Hi Destin,
In one part of your video you say that the rotors act like a big fan blowing down the air to keep the helicopter aloft, but this is not correct. The air being pushed down, the so-called "rotor wash", is not the force that keeps the helicopter in the air. Each of the rotor blades is an airfoil (in one section of your video you can see the profile of the rotor blade); as the rotor blades spin, each rotor generates lift like the wing of an airplane. The lift generated by the rotor blades is what keeps the helicopter in the air.

The swash plate varies the pitch of each blade as they rotate through a full rotation cycle, which alters the lift generated by each blade. Varying the lift of each blade at all points through the rotation cycle is how the helicopter can move side to side and back to front (pitch and roll, respectively), etc.

The tail rotor blades are also airfoils, and generate lift, and with varied pitch, counter act the yaw force of the rotor blades and allow the helicopter to swing it it's nose left to right (yaw).

I love your videos! Thank you for the time and effort that goes into them!

Destin, you need to explore the other side of this - because planes really fall more like bricks. They are not designed to be gliders, and without sufficient thrust they can't maintain lift... These leads to an interesting paradox - small 2 engine planes suffer from twice as many catastrophic failures as single-engine planes. When a 2 engine plane loses 1 engine it lacks the power to maintain flight, and since each engine has the same likelihood to fail, independent of each other, they are actually more dangerous than their smaller single-engine counterparts.
-Shawn

Here's the other thing about what Gerry said about the 50-60 vs. 15 knots though. An airplane, given this higher speed and longer gliding distance, has a better opportunity to properly search for a safe landing area. In a helicopter, if your engine fails, you've got whatever momentum you had built up to move you in a forward direction, which, if you aren't already, is not enough time to get you over a safe landing area. Albeit, there is a wider range of available landing space for helicopters than airplanes simply because helicopters can land more vertically than horizontally, but imagine your engine fails over uneven terrain. Autorotation or not, you're going down and it is not going to be pretty.

If anybody wants to try this in a simulator pick up Take on Helicopters.  It's made by the same team the produces the Arma series of mil-sim games (although ToH is strictly a Heli sim, not military).  One of the lessons is in using autorotation in the event of an engine failure.  There are a ton of other things to learn as well.  I'd strongly recommend playing it with pedals and HOTAS if possible.

Your stated that when a helicopter is flying normal under power the rotor acts like a fan blowing air down (to support flight).  That is incorrect.  As the rotor blades are wings (airfoils) that by rotational movement through air create lift enabling the helicopter to move forward or back by tilting the entire rotor while the collective adjust the airfoil pitch (angle of attack) to increase or decrease lift so the helicopter increases or decreases altitude. Stated simpler: in powered flight it flies by lift and unpowered it glides by drag created by the rotating wing just as fixed wing airplane does

hey Dustin I fly rc helicopters and much like their larger cousins. the model can also auto rotate. in order to do it you need forward momentum and a small bit of "negative pitch " which builds the head speed back up. right before you hit the ground you go positive pitch and pull the nose up slightly and revs  up the rotor speed even higher which gives yoy enough for a gentle touch down. they are awesome especially when you have $3000 ridding in you not messing it up. lol I always thought the big birds used the same method. (negative pitch) ??

At 3:08, that's false. It's not working like a fan. Air does get displaced downwards, but the primary lift force comes from the pressure differential on the top and bottom of each blade. Just like an airplane wing, and just like a propeller on smaller aircraft.

That is how autogiros work (gyrocopters) constantly in autorotation. You forgot to mention the interesting piece of kit that allows the rotor to keep rotating when the engine fails.  The sprag clutch. Without it, the engine would stay connected to the system, and either slow down or completely seize the  rotors, turning the helicopter into the rock that guy was talking about.

This is all going to sound super judgey, but as a long time viewer and patron of this channel I've loved how you can break down complex things into digestible nuggets, and I've shared your helicopter deep dive many times. This I don't feel I can share, because it's so crammed full of fast information that I think it could be alienating to people who don't already understand some helicopter physics.

Having watched your Helicopter Deep Dive, I really feel like this didn't explain what happens in a clear way. It could be explained as simply as: the pilot changes the angle of the blades so the wind from falling speeds up their rotation, then the pilot changes the angle back to normal so the blade's new rotation is spent slowing the descent.

Don't get me wrong, the video does cover everything. It does eventually say that 'he bleeds off the rotational energy in the form of lift', which not only is a confusing way to say it but it is said REALLY quickly- it's the most important part! Also the fact that the pinwheel vs fan effect happens simultaneously on different parts of the blade is interesting but really not integral to understanding why this works, yet the video shows this before even explaining how they relate to each other. Lastly, the fact that spinning too fast can damage the blades is kinda irrelevant to the physics of why it works at all; it's just something they have to be careful of.

The ultimate problem is that the video initially tries to say that falling can spin up the blades, then talks about three other complicated things before finally finishing the point (of using the new spin to slow down the fall). Even during the actual autorotation scene this isn't fully explained, like at the end when it is said that "right here at the bottom he's gonna flare it and when he flares it that trades off the kinetic energy in the system into... There we go..." That was so close, it was nearly explained fully! Even so, using terms like 'kinetic energy' instead of 'rotation' and the very unspecific 'system' still doesn't help.

On a positive note, loved the adventures you had on the glacier! And your kids are just the cutest.

Love the video, and reintroduction to the concept of autorotation. I'm curious on the difference on how the guy landed the model helicopter using autorotation vs a landing with a full sized helicopter. Understandably, a model copter can withstand forces people piloting them can't, but is it a physical limitation of the full sized copter or human comfort that designates the variation in the landing method? Specifically, the model copter mostly dropped and used most of the energy to hover before getting to the ground, whereas the full sized version had you coasting most of the time down. I would have suspected more fast dips downward to build up rotational speed to convert into downward thrust.
Neil specifically said, show me how you can make a helicopter with the blades NOT turning not fall like a brick.  Because it might not be possible for him to get any smarter.

Ok, so when the helicopter falls down the air blowing past the rotor spins it up giving it momentum and kinetic energy, right before landing the blades are turned so that the kinetic energy in the blades is used to press air downwards, dampening the vertical velocity? It sounds simple, but I just don't understand how there's enough kinetic energy stored unless there's a huge flywheel (which again would add to the weight which has to be accelerated upwards to dampen the fall). Wouldn't the kinetic energy in the rotor be roughly the same as the kinetic energy of the falling helicopter body in order for this to work?
